#ICYMI Auburn recently broke ground on our National Pan-Hellenic Council Legacy Plaza::: a symbolic and functional space that will recognize and celebrate the legacy of Black Greek organizations and African American culture at the land-grant institution.

The ceremony took place near the recently opened The Edge at Central Dining facility::: close to the Campus Green area::: Jordan-Hare Stadium and the Academic Classroom and Laboratory Complex that is expected to be completed in spring 2022.

Hundreds of #Auburn alumni attended the annual Black Alumni Weekend festivities Nov. 12-14::: returning to campus for everything from a special tailgate celebration to an awards ceremony.

The three-day event began with a reception on Nov. 12 at The Hotel at Auburn University & Dixon Conference Center and was followed the next morning by a tailgate on Cater Lawn in anticipation of the Auburn Football game against the Mississippi State Bulldogs.

On Nov. 14::: attendees then experienced the Black Alumni Weekend Brunch and Awards Ceremony at the Student Activities Center::: with the following alumni being recognized as award recipients from each college and school for their outstanding achievements: Apollos Abercrombie ‚Äô16::: Brenda M. Allen ‚Äô97::: Joshua Ekandem ‚Äô07::: Sophia Bracy Harris ‚Äô72::: Jerlando Jackson ‚Äô97::: Lawrence Martin ‚Äô07::: Jocelyn Richardson ‚Äô99::: Jamesa Stokes ‚Äô14::: Vonnie Stone ‚Äô95::: K-Rob Thomas ‚Äô01 and Marquita Winder ‚Äô10. #WarEagle

#ICYMI The legacy of Harold A. Franklin::: #Auburn's first African American student::: will live on forever through a specially designed desegregation marker expanse that was unveiled on campus at a celebration ceremony on Thursday.

The area near the marker‚Äîlocated adjacent to the Ralph Brown Draughon Library where he first registered for classes along a path that leads to the university‚Äôs iconic Samford Hall‚Äîcommemorates Franklin‚Äôs courageous efforts to desegregate the land-grant institution and has been expanded with hardscaping and landscaping enhancements::: including a new bronze plaque and circular::: brick courtyard.

Franklin::: who passed away on Sept. 9 at the age of 88::: integrated Auburn as the university‚Äôs first Black student on Jan. 4::: 1964::: coming to the Plains as a Graduate School enrollee.

#Auburn broke ground today on our National Pan-Hellenic Council Legacy Plaza::: a symbolic and functional space that will recognize and celebrate the legacy of Black Greek organizations and African American culture at the land-grant institution. #WarEagle

‚ö†Ô∏è Be prepared for delays and heavy traffic as you‚Äôre making your way to campus this week.

City of Auburn::: AL - City Government
8 November::: 15:29 ¬∑

‚ö†Ô∏è RAILROAD CROSSING UPDATE : The railroad crossings on North College Street::: North Gay Street and North Ross Street will close tomorrow::: Nov. 9::: as CSX continues work in Auburn. The crossing on Old Stage Road is now closed.

Work on Saugahatchee Road is expected to finish late tonight::: and work on East University Drive will continue tomorrow. All crossings are expected to reopen no later than Thursday. The Dean Road and Donahue Drive crossings will remain open.

Please be careful and plan ahead if one of these crossings is part of your regular commute. Please note::: scheduling these closures is up to CSX and the amount of work needed to make improvements at each street crossing. Thank you for your patience as CSX maintains these crossings!

Find more info at news.auburnalabama.org/article/Top%20Stories/4322.

The Presidential Search Advisory Committee is pleased to share the presidential leadership statement and position profile with the Auburn Family. The leadership statement includes #Auburn‚Äôs strengths and aspirations as well as the opportunities that await the institution‚Äôs 21st president.

The position profile is the outcome of the many public listening sessions hosted by the Presidential Search Advisory Committee and the executive search firm. As part of a partnership between #Auburn and the Alabama Department of Public Health::: a KICK COVID vaccine clinic will be offered to students::: faculty and fans on campus during Auburn Football gameday festivities Sept. 25.

The clinic will take place outdoors at the north side of Auburn Arena from noon to one hour after the game on Sept. 25. Individuals who receive their first or second vaccine dose on campus will receive a $75 Auburn University Bookstore gift card. Individuals may also get vaccinated between Sept. 11 and Oct. 2 and upload proof of vaccination to kickcovid19.com. They will receive a $75 campus bookstore gift card by mail.

column3:
Since this is a criminal matter I‚Äôm pretty certain that if/when an arrest is made the frat will be named by the police and in turn Auburn University. I‚Äôm also pretty certain that if Auburn were to ‚Äúname the frat‚Äù or the accused frat member and nobody was arrested the University would be set up for a lawsuit. I would also speculate that if the Frat or suspect was named before an arrest was made it could potentially make the prosecutors job more difficult.
As a concerned person pointed out in an earlier post::: ‚ÄúAuburn must do the right thing‚Äù::: and I agree. I think ‚Äúright thing‚Äù is for AU to allow the police to investigate the matter and make a determination. Perhaps we should let the justice system work even know it sometimes takes longer than I or anyone else would like.
column4: Auburn should be working hard to educate students from freshman year through their senior year about consent. What consent actually means and additionally::: what the legal and university consequences are to those that break the law. All students should be mandated to complete online training annually. Many employers require this type of training to be done::: so I know it‚Äôs available.
column5: They've absolutely got to name the fraternity house and let the chips fall where they may. It's a matter of public safety::: just like notifying the neighbors when pedophiles move nearby
column6: You will never make some people happy with any decision you make. These crimes need to be investigated to the fullest extent of the law and those persons who are accountable need to be held as such. Outside of that we as a society have to start acting like we have some sense and treat these cases as individual events that deserve full attention BUT we cannot and must not let emotion drown out reality or the facts of each situation. Blaming Auburn University is very misguided if the university is doing (and I personally know they are) everything within their power to reduce sexual assault. You need someone to blame? Blame the perp.
column7: Just think about how many sexual assaults go unreported. This is a much larger problem than I think many realize.
column8: If transparency is such a ‚Äúcritical component‚Äù to the safety of students::: honor that and name the fraternity that students should be avoiding for their safety.
column9: I haven't seen all the details and am concerned::: obviously concerned::: since I have a daughter that attends. Would like more information::: has there been a police report filed? Sexual assault is and should be a serious accusation and absolutely unacceptable! It should be addressed as should false accusations or painting a broad brush of guilt is equally concerning. I certainly hope that women and men on campus are also helping and protecting "sisters" and friends from being vulnerable and put in dangerous situations.
column11: You guys need to address the issue of safety at Skybar as well. It was bad when I was a student and it is obviously still a problem.

column45:
An interesting article from this week's The Economist magazine about Auburn alum::: Tim Cook:

Tim Cook is the chief executive of Apple::: the world's most valuable firm with a market value of $2.5Trillion. Over 80% of that has been amassed during the tenure of Tim Cook. No other chief executive has created more absolute value for shareholders. He took Steve Job's creation and made it better and bigger.

As Tim Cook celebrated his tenth anniversary as Apple's boss on August 24th::: no one made a peep. He has staged what is arguably the greatest succession success in technology. When he took over from Jobs the company had a market value of $434 Billion. Annual sales surged from $108 Billion to $274 Billion last year. Net profit more than doubled to $57 Billion turning Apple into the world's most profitable company. Less widely noticed::: during his tenure the "Apple economy" - its own annual revenue plus everything other companies make on its platforms has grown sevenfold to more than $1 Trillion.

My editorial... I feel sure Auburn does not receive its due. Too often other schools talk about their football player who can run faster with a football than our football player. Big deal. Auburn alums are changing the world.

Taylor::: a special education doctoral candidate in the Auburn University College of Education and master‚Äôs student in the Harbert College of Business::: recently formed the Young Professionals in Training program at Auburn as a mentoring and tutoring program for students grades 5-12 from underrepresented populations near Auburn.

The program‚Äîaimed at exposing students to majors and career paths at the university‚Äîinvolves faculty::: staff::: students and alumni serving as mentors who meet with mentees once a month to build relationships and discuss topics::: such as social and emotional health::: community projects and career paths. #WarEagle

#Auburn is going contactless. Tiger Card can now be added as a mobile student ID card to compatible iPhone::: Apple Watch or Android devices. Students will be able to use the mobile ID to access campus buildings::: purchase meals and more.

The campus-issued mobile ID adds a level of convenience and accessibility to the popular Tiger Card and can be used anywhere a plastic ID card is used::: both on and off campus. Once provisioned::: users simply present an iPhone::: Apple Watch or Android phone to NFC-enabled devices to pay for food::: vending or laundry or open exterior and interior doors to campus buildings and residence halls.

Learn more about having Tiger Card on your mobile device: http://www.auburn.edu/administration/tigercard/

I keep seeing people posting comments like ‚Äúno one alive was a slave or knew a former slave::: so why are we celebrating Juneteenth?‚Äù

What an asinine comment. It‚Äôs about rememberance and reflection. You know::: like a lot of holidays.

Columbus Day is celebrated every year::: yet Columbus has been dead for centuries and no one alive knew him personally.

Christmas celebrates Jesus Christ‚Äôs birth::: yet no one alive knew him personally nor know anyone who witnessed Jesus‚Äô birth firsthand

Most Americans celebrate ID4::: yet no one is alive who knew the soldiers who fought for our freedom in the late 1700s

I could go on. There‚Äôs nothing wrong with honoring those who had to go through hell and back.

Auburn has now extended the third phase of its COVID-19 vaccine distribution plan to include area community residents age 12 and older. The third phase also continues to provide inoculations to Auburn University retirees as well as the family members and dependents of the university‚Äôs employees. The Pfizer vaccine is now available to those as young as 12::: with the vaccine by other manufacturers being accessible to those 18 and older. Those who have not yet received a first dose of the vaccine can set an appointment through the scheduler website. Should any Auburn student or employee not see available appointments::: they can send an email to ahealthieru@auburn.edu. Once an appointment has been set::: Auburn will send a confirmation email to the person requesting the vaccine.

For more information on Auburn‚Äôs phased approach to vaccine distribution::: go to the university‚Äôs COVID-19 vaccine information webpage::: which includes how-to videos on the process of getting a COVID-19 vaccine through Auburn.

http://auburn.edu/covid-resource-center/vaccine-information/

column1:
#Auburn is planning a full in-person::: on-campus academic and student life experience for fall 2021.

The decision was made in consultation with state and local health officials and with input from shared governance groups representing students::: faculty and staff.

Although specific plans are still in development::: we expect that when fall semester begins on Aug. 16:

‚Ä¢ Course offerings::: and the manner in which the courses are delivered::: will resemble a typical fall semester.

‚Ä¢ Elements of campus life that involve groups of people::: such as housing::: dining::: recreation::: events::: travel and transportation::: are expected to return to more normal operations.

‚Ä¢ The campus community will be asked to follow certain health and safety precautions. Specific guidance will be outlined this summer.

Additional details about the university‚Äôs fall plans::: including information about the academic calendar::: student life and COVID-19 vaccines and testing::: are forthcoming and will be posted on the university‚Äôs website.

The university‚Äôs fall plans are based on the assumption that the incidence of COVID-19 infection will continue to decrease in Alabama and that a significant percentage of students::: faculty and staff will be vaccinated by the end of summer. We will continue to monitor public health scenarios and is prepared to adjust plans accordingly.

Throughout the 2020-21 academic year::: we implemented several health and safety protocols to safely allow as many on-campus academic::: research and student activities as possible. The university‚Äôs positivity rates have remained consistently low due to continued adherence to safety measures::: including face coverings::: physical distancing::: sentinel testing and hand hygiene::: among others.

Our vaccination distribution efforts are ongoing::: with the vaccine now available to all students::: faculty and staff. While the university is not currently mandating vaccination as a condition for return to campus in the fall::: all campus community members are strongly encouraged to receive the vaccine. Additionally::: the university will continue to offer COVID-19 testing through the Auburn University Medical Clinic and provide resources and support for individuals who have been affected by the virus. #AHealthierU

I went to Auburn. It is a great place. However::: it is not immune from the evil and hate of racism etc.

Ever heard of yik yak? It was an anonymous app where you could post a tiny statement and local people could comment. Popular at Auburn some years ago. Very basic app. In that app there were frequent disgusting and sometimes disturbing comments. Not all racist either. Misogynistic. Xenophobic.

They appeared on there because of the relative anonymity of the app. Things they believe/hold in their mind yet know it isn‚Äôt okay to say in person.

Minneapolis may be far from Lee County::: but racism and hate know no boundaries.

Finally I‚Äôll leave with the anecdotal story of an Auburn student vehemently saying how he did not like::: support::: or care for any black people on the football team. He was blatantly telling a small group of people that he didn‚Äôt care about them simply because they weren‚Äôt white.

The media is trash in all directions. That doesn‚Äôt mean these problems are completely made up. Difference between completely made up and manipulated by the media.

There are still very hateful racists out there.

column3: Awesome üá∫üá∏üá∫üá∏üá∫üá∏I was at Auburn finishing my degree while my husband was an army helicopter pilot in Vietnam. Everyone at Auburn was kind and supportive. When I missed several days of classes to meet my husband in Hawaii for 4 days of R&R my professors allowed me to make up work missed . When he returned I had student teaching left to do and Auburn allowed me to do it as a transient student supervised by Troy univ. so I could do it near Ft. Rucker where he was stationed. Troy gave 1 less credit hour for student teaching than Auburn did::: and I was allowed to graduate 1 hour short. I have never forgotten these kindnesses ::: and I am so very pleased and proud to know that my beloved Auburn still supports the military .War Eagle!
column4: We‚Äôre an Auburn family. 4 of us went there. My son went there as an undergraduate. He graduated with the first class of the medical school (VCOM) with help from the military. He met his wife at Auburn as well as me meeting my husband there. War Eagle!!!!!

They called me and checked in several times::: and were always there to answer questions.

I will forever be grateful for the support they gave our military family during my sons health issues while my husband was deployed. War Eagle!

Holmes‚Äîwho teaches in the School of Architecture::: Planning and Landscape Architecture in the Auburn University College of Architecture::: Design and Construction‚Äîis continuing a collaborative project to help improve the design::: function and efficacy of coastal infrastructure nationally.

Buoyed by a renewed grant from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers::: he and his team are committed to delivering economic::: social and environmental benefits through research that focuses on innovative design concepts for water-related infrastructure like levees::: jetties and dams. #WarEagle

It all began for Christopher Lepczyk out in the wilds of the upper Great Lake states.

Growing up in Michigan::: he spent his fair share of time exploring the outdoors::: budding a love of nature that to this day fuels his passion as an award-winning professor in the Auburn University School of Forestry and Wildlife Sciences.

Lepczyk now guides #Auburn students along their path::: teaching them a fond appreciation for nature. He said that his biggest hope is that his students work to make ‚Äúbetter decisions in how they live and treat the environment.‚Äù

This past week::: a new ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Test‚Äù sentinel testing program launched at Auburn with much success::: setting in place a smooth process for random COVID-19 testing of Auburn employees and students to provide an ongoing snapshot of campus health. In a video::: Kimberly Braxton-Lloyd::: associate dean of Clinical Affairs and Outreach and Gilliland Professor in the Harrison School of Pharmacy::: recently offered the details of the program that is being managed on campus by Auburn‚Äôs expert faculty::: staff and students.

Kerry Inger wants her students to see the interesting aspects of tax in everyday situations::: and especially those that aren‚Äôt every day::: like how tax laws can affect a baseball caught at a Major League Baseball game.

‚ÄúIs that baseball taxable? It can depend on the player and situation:::‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAn ordinary foul ball::: no. But a key home run in the World Series::: most definitely.‚Äù

Inger::: associate professor in the Harbert College of Business‚Äô School of Accountancy::: teaches undergraduate and graduate tax accounting classes. The classes involve different approaches to teaching::: but Inger brings out the best in her students::: no matter the level.

An #Auburn researcher has joined with European scientists in an attempt to decipher the disease process caused by one of the world‚Äôs most harmful plant pathogens::: Xylella fastidiosa.

The bacterium‚Äôs impact has been nothing short of catastrophic in both the U.S. and Europe. Originating in the Americas::: Xylella fastidiosa has caused a crisis in the European Union::: where the bacterium was first recognized in the southern heel of Italy in 2013. Tens of thousands of gnarled olive trees::: some of them hundreds of years old::: are withering and dying::: destroying the livelihoods of families that have relied on the centuries-old groves for generations.

OCM.AUBURN.EDU
Auburn professor teams with European scientists seeking to save olive trees from deadly pathogen

While working to complete his doctorate in mathematics::: Ozbolt worked with NASA leadership and seven other members of the Space Communications and Navigation::: or SCaN::: Internship Project::: or SIP::: to successfully adapt a 10-week program at NASA's Glenn Research Center to the virtual realm due to the coronavirus outbreak. The team and internship supervisors used software and a digital platform to create a virtual work environment::: and despite the challenges posed by being forced to work on projects online from different parts of the country rather than in person in Ohio::: they were able to perform at a high level and complete the program.

column11: One of the great honors of my career as a student on the Plains of Auburn occurred during the last quarter of my Freshman year. I was selected along with seven other AFROTC Cadets for the University Flag detail. Each quarter in rotation the Army::: then Naval::: & finally the Air Force ROTC detachment Cadets & Midshipmen would each morning & evening raise & lower the large American flag outside of Samford Hall. This signaled the beginning & ending of the duty day for these ROTC students & faculty staff. I to this day recall with not only great nostalgia and honor at having been selected by my Upper Class Men for this traditional honor but the respect my fellow AU student classmates showed us whenever they learned about this daily ritual conducted by the AU ROTC units. This ole retired Airman is very pleased to see our sister Army ROTC unit showing this great respect & remembrance of the 911 victims. ‚ù§Ô∏èüá∫üá∏üëçüëå

The group of undergraduate and graduate students::: staff::: A&P::: faculty and alumni representatives have been examining current diversity::: equity and inclusion issues and will recommend steps leading to a stronger and more impactful #Auburn for students::: faculty::: staff::: alumni and the communities served by the university.

Lindsey Olive didn‚Äôt choose to attend #Auburn because it‚Äôs in her hometown::: but because it would provide room for career exploration and vast study abroad opportunities.

By the time Olive graduates this year::: she will have chronicled trips to Nepal::: Jordan::: Italy and New York::: all study abroad options offered through the Auburn University College of Human Sciences.

Fittingly::: the world traveler is a global studies major::: although it wasn‚Äôt her first choice.

‚ÄúI changed my major several times before I landed on global studies. I was drawn to the major because of its focus on problem-based learning::: the building of cross-cultural competencies and the search for ways to improve the quality of life through different avenues. Thank you for this article that highlights Lindsey‚Äôs global studies experiences at AU::: and thank you to those of you who chose to congratulate her here.‚ù§Ô∏è The world is overflowing with critics looking for their moment to be right::: better than::: and an expert over other people::: even in response to an article like this. What this article didn‚Äôt share is that she graduated today summa cum laude::: and an Honors Scholar. She served during her time at AU as a peer advisor::: an Involvement ambassador::: CHS ambassador::: and an AU IQLA Awards student ambassador at the United Nations among other things. She received and kept for 4 years her academic scholarship as well as received others. She lived at home and worked jobs getting up at 4am slinging donuts::: delivering flowers::: and also helping us run our local small business. SHE paid for her education at Auburn and her study abroad experiences through her own hard work and choices and by applying for and interviewing for scholarships. As an alum myself::: there is no doubt that she embodies the Auburn creed and spirit if anyone does. She gained so much from her global studies education and supply chain management education::: and as she leaves Auburn we just can‚Äôt thank enough all of the people at AU that invested in her~ there have been many. Congratulations
and War Eagle to all of today‚Äôs graduates!

column5: Proud of all of the graduates::: but need to say what I‚Äôm truly feeling today. Graduation ceremonies get postponed in May::: rescheduled for August. A cap and gown get hung in the closet to wait for August. Our daughter takes a teaching job in TX. Arranges for flight home for graduation. Then::: she gets notified that the rescheduled ceremony has been indefinitely postponed. Heartbreak! I appreciate the graduation box and she does have her diploma. She canceled her flight because going to the stadium to get a picture and see your name displayed on the video screen is not worth the time off of work::: the flight::: etc. The chances of her participating in a graduation ceremony is nonexistent at this point. I get that not everyone will understand this or sympathize::: but she worked so hard for this moment and it was taken away from her TWICE! But::: by all means::: let‚Äôs schedule football games in JHS for 15:::000 - 20:::000 people to attend IN PERSON. The same JHS where graduation ceremonies were going to be held. I‚Äôm not mad at the student athletes because this was not their decision and I know that several have made the personal decision to not play due to health risks. Allowing for football games is a money-based decision. It‚Äôs very sad and hard to watch UA and other universities hold in-person graduation ceremonies knowing that TODAY would have been a moment to celebrate our daughter and her achievement with family in attendance cheering her on. Please understand that despite all of this::: I still believe in Auburn and love it::: as does our daughter and the rest of the Auburn family. However::: today is a struggle. War Eagle.

EAGLES Program Auburn University
30 July 2020 –≥.::: 09:09 ¬∑

THEY DID IT! Anna::: Bradley::: and Josh are the first students to complete the initial two-year EAGLES program through Auburn‚Äôs College of Education. Our innovative EAGLES program equips students with intellectual disabilities to pursue fulfilling work::: live independently::: and achieve their post-school goals. Because of the generosity and support from the Auburn Family::: EAGLES students walked Auburn‚Äôs campus with their peers::: took classes::: created lasting friendships::: lived in a residence hall::: joined campus clubs::: gained employment::: participated in student organizations::: and had the chance to live out their Auburn dreams. To mark the end of their time at Auburn::: Anna::: Bradley::: Josh and their fellow graduates received commencement boxes in the spring. But their journey is not ending! All three students were invited back to continue their education in the Advanced EAGLES Program. We are excited to share their joy and celebration of this milestone with you in this video: Auburn University College of Education Auburn University Foundation SERC Department

As part of preparations for the upcoming fall 2020 semester::: we have issued a modified fall academic calendar::: prioritizing the health of the campus community and mitigating the spread of COVID-19.

Key dates for the semester include:

- Aug. 17: Classes begin
- Oct. 8-9: Fall break is suspended; classes will meet
- Nov. 23-24: Classes will meet on these two days of Thanksgiving week; students do not have to return to campus after Nov. 24
- Nov. 25-27: Thanksgiving break
- Nov. 30 to Dec. 1: Student reading days
- Dec. 2-8: Final exams delivered remotely

OCM.AUBURN.EDU
Auburn announces modified fall 2020 academic calendar

column7:
We have two of these cafes here in town::: and they do pretty well::: especially the one near a gym. I think they sell a tea and shake combo for like $12 (I only know it's more than $10 because that's the limited time special price.)

Seems silly to pay for something that you an buy and mix up at home::: but they keep the wide range of flavors available so that's a plus for not having multiple tubs of stuff around the house.

But more power to him::: and the best advice is to know when to get out of the market::: cause it won't last forever. It will certainly take attention to keep up with sales trends and get out before the market falls::: whether you're selling nutrition drinks or chevron pocket tees.

column1:
Dear Auburn Family:::

The events of the past 10 days have been painful for me and::: I‚Äôm certain::: for every member of the Auburn Family. The pain of yet another brutal death on our streets; the pain of rights infringed during peaceful protest; the pain of fear; and the pain of frustration::: wondering if anything will ever change.

While we all have a lot of questions::: it is clear that something has to change::: both in society and on our campus. As your president::: I commit that we as an institution will seek meaningful action to confront the pain::: fear::: systemic racism and injustice faced by the black community.

In the past week::: many courses of action have been proposed::: including ridding campus of hurtful symbols::: creating campus-wide conversations::: building relevant coursework and training::: and strengthening recruitment of African American students and faculty. Just this morning::: I listened to concerns and recommendations from a group of African American student leaders who represent many areas of campus. Their love for Auburn is sincere::: and their thoughts for moving forward are heartfelt and constructive. I came away with renewed sensitivity to the state of the nation and our university and an enhanced sense of urgency for positive change.

There will be more conversations::: involving students::: faculty::: staff and alumni. These conversations will lead to learning that will lead to action.

In the near term::: I will form a task force to guide the university through meaningful change. Members of the task force will be asked to gather ideas from the Auburn Family::: prioritize next steps::: develop implementation plans and hold us accountable as a university. We will soon provide more information.

As we chart a course of action::: I call on all students::: faculty and staff to embrace a number of imperatives:

1. We must be honest with each other and recognize that discrimination against African Americans and other people of color exists and is wrong. There is hate that is festering. We can and must do something about it.

2. We must remember that silence is not acceptable. When we see something wrong::: we must speak up.

3. We must treat all people with respect and civility as individuals::: not as groups.

4. We must demand that all laws of the land are administered fairly and equally.

5. We must listen to the voices of those who have been disenfranchised and do what we can to help.

In the past::: Auburn has done some things right::: and we‚Äôve done some things wrong. We need to do more. We will work together::: and we will do better.

Sincerely:::

Jay Gogue
President

To my Christian peers in these comments... MAN many of y'all need to reevaluate how you've chosen to ignore God's word entirely. If Jesus didn't stand for prejudice and discrimination:::
why are you? If you want to read some interesting stuff::: I've got some verses from the Bible of Bullcrap on my page. My mom added some verse too in the comments. Maybe some of y'all can relate. To the Christians who are clearly living by the Word::: thank you. Everyone needs to read this letter.
...............
.......

I've had a lot on my heart recently and decided to pray. I've never felt the way I did when writing this. I asked God to lead me. You will see where the words change.

Dear Christians:::
I have been fighting the need to speak to you. I have been telling God::: ‚Äúnot me::: not me.‚Äù I did not have the words. I do not have the words. God has the words. The world is on fire. No longer can I be silent.
First::: forgiveness and love are at the center of all Christ‚Äôs actions. Thus::: it should be at the center of ours. We do not have to support or endorse violence and damage. We do not have to agree with people‚Äôs life decisions. We do not have to like every person involved. We do have to display love and forgiveness. We cannot judge others for what they do. We can set the example. We can lead the charge.
Where are the Ephesians 6:10-18 Christians? Where are the Christians wearing the full armor of God ready to go into battle? Where are the Christians who denounce the hypocrites? Where are the Christians who let God lead their spirit instead of money::: politics::: and the world? Where are the Christians who stand against hate and bigotry? Where are the Christians who stand against prejudice and discrimination?

Why do you stay silent? Why do you sit idly by? Why do you look away and say::: ‚ÄúIt has nothing to do with me; I cannot support something that includes rioting; I will look only to one human for all of the answers‚Äù? Why do you pretend like the people in charge are made perfect?
Let this be said here and now! Christians! Followers of the Lord Our God! Believers in Christ! THERE IS ONLY ONE WHO WAS MADE PERFECT. THERE IS ONLY ONE WHO WALKED THE EARTH AS PERFECT MAN AND GOD. HIS NAME IS JESUS CHRIST AND THIS IS NOT HIS SECOND COMING.
Do not fall under the rule of false prophets! Did Jesus not sit with tax collectors and prostitutes?! Did he not flip the tables of the pharisees who were abusing his father‚Äôs house?! Did he not call out those who would stone others?!
Who of you is without sin?! Who of you is without prejudice?! Who of you has the authority to decide that the color of one‚Äôs skin is worth less than yours?!
He is the creator of life! He created us different and beautiful! Why do you stand by and watch his children be destroyed! ?Why do you not speak up against false prophets!? Why do you not call out those who would use his name for personal gain!? Why do you sit idle!?
Here I tell you! Truly are those who speak blessed by the Lord! Those who follow with full faith are placed in the house of the Lord! Those who lead as Christ lead::: those who followed as the disciples followed! Why do you sit idle?!
Here I tell you! Blessed are those who reject the world! Blessed are those who know my word! Blessed are those who hear my voice! Why do you sit idle?!
Here I tell you! No human on this earth is perfect! Did he not remove those who failed to follow my decree from power?! Did he not call out against those who would use his name to hurt the innocent?! Why do you sit idle?!
Here I tell you! Christians::: SPEAK UP! SPEAK UP! I equipped you with my book not for you to sit silently::: but for to proclaim my name in the streets! For you to lead and protect and serve! I did not equip you to hide behind walls and pretty words! I did not equip you to follow blindly!
Here I tell you! I am your Sheppard! You follow where I lead! If I have lost one sheep::: I have not forgotten the ninety-nine! I will go after the one and bring them back to the flock for safety! Why do you sit idle my children?! Why do you sit idle?!
Here I tell you! Did I not give you the skills to fight hypocrisy?! Did I not give you the heart to deny Satan?! Why do you sit idle?!
Here I tell you! I will love an honest non-believer before a hypocritical follower! You will stand children! You will support!
My house is a house of love and safety! Do you I not love you though you sin?! Do I not comfort you though you fail?! Do I not listen to you though you deny me?! Why do you sit idle!
Here I tell you! STAND UP CHILDREN OF GOD! THIS IS WHERE YOU SPEAK! PUT ON THE ARMOR I EQUIPPED YOU WITH! FIGHT WITH LOVE AND FORGIVENESS! STOP ALLOWING MY NAME TO BE SULLIED BY THOSE WHO WOULD ABUSE IT! STOP BLINDLY FOLLOWING ANYONE WHO SAYS MY NAME! YOU WILL KNOW WHEN I AM SPEAKING! ALL YOU HAVE TO DO IS PRAY! NO LONGER WILL I ALLOW THIS! REFLECT::: PRAY::: HAVE FAITH::: AND KNOW THAT I AM WITH YOU! I AM WITH YOU! SO STAND UP MY CHILDREN AND GO FORTH AND FIGHT!

I applaud Auburn‚Äôs desire to change for the better of all people.

I‚Äôm going to be honest here. I will no longer support or watch anyone::: team::: university::: tv show::: or anything anymore that desires change but acts like and addresses discrimination as if it solely exists and needs to change for one color of people.

Refusing to address this situation as an entire human race instead of it being black this and white that.

When you remove ethnicity/race from applications::: quit labeling things by color(problems across the board)::: and remove everyone from office who has spent time there and done nothing to fix the issues::: I might return.

This goes above black and white. The racism will continue if it‚Äôs coming from any source. It exists in every source.

The ways we tried to enact change in the past aren‚Äôt working. Saying you will do this thing and improve is the same old song and dance I see in this message.

To enact real change::: it takes an effort from the whole. That isn‚Äôt happening.

I sincerely hope that everyone will wake up soon and realize how approaching the situation will be better when we do it as a united people of every race and color.

What means something to one person means something completely different to another. Your attempt at understanding is one sided.

It‚Äôs time we teach our children that any label of color is wrong. Even when it comes to movements asking for change.

Good luck. I hope everyone gets off the repeat train of history and opens their eyes to the manipulation and the sources causing us to continue this madness.

If we don‚Äôt::: this exact situation and conversation will happen again. The same way it has since the 60‚Äôs. Open your eyes::: ears::: and minds.

I‚Äôm out AU family. Until things actually change and racism isn‚Äôt used to fight racism.

I calmly (I know that is hard to believe) told them they had an opportunity to give her a chance and possibly pledge her and make a change for the better or they could remain status quo. They went for status quo that year and I was so mad::: angry and hurt I could not see straight. Tonight I saw this. I cried. In 21 very short years Auburn haa come a long way. We still have 21 years and 42 years and 63 years of progress to still make::: but this is the Creed!

Dear Auburn Family:::

Our nation is hurting. For the last few months::: we have hurt physically::: financially and otherwise from the coronavirus. Now::: recent events of racial injustice are hurting us in many ways that words often find inadequate to fully express.

While we acknowledge the painful reality that prejudice and bigotry exist::: we stand resolute that they have no place in the Auburn Family. As an institution that values and embraces each individual::: we oppose hate and exclusion and acts that promote them.

It was on my heart to reaffirm Auburn‚Äôs values. I‚Äôm confident that we::: together::: will work toward change and healing.

Jay Gogue
President
